page.title: 04FORTHAMPTON-LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: The church of St. Mary the Virgin is built of blue Lias rubble with roofs of tiles and Cotswold stone slates. The oldest part of the church is a 13th Century stone altar which is one of the very few of these altars to survive the Reformation. The original chapel was enlerged to a church in the 14th Century but several changes and restorations have taken place since then; the most recent in 1893 by J.R. Yorke. Just outside the church are the village stocks and whipping post complete with iron manacles and seating which have survived almost intact from 1787. At the bottom of the hill is the Pound Pond, which is believed to have been the ducking pool for scolding wives.
